title: Prelude and Fugue in C Major

prelude.tempo: No tempo marking (typically Andante or Moderato)
prelude.historicalNote: Made famous by Gounod's Ave Maria superimposition (1853)

sections.name: First Departure
sections.description: Explores related keys through secondary dominants

sections.name: Sequential Development
sections.description: Chain of fifths sequence with increasing chromaticism

sections.name: Return and Preparation
sections.description: Gradual return to tonic, alternating inversions

sections.name: Pedal Point and Resolution
sections.description: Dominant pedal resolving to final tonic

technicalFeatures: Left hand provides bass notes and harmonic foundation
Right hand arpeggios span approximately one octave
No melodic theme in traditional sense - harmony IS the content

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: Broken chord pattern C-E-G-C-E; LH: Bass C, inner voice E providing 5ths and octaves
notableFeatures: Establishes the iconic 16th-note broken chord pattern
Pattern: bass-chord tone-chord tone-chord tone-chord tone (repeated)
Each measure presents ONE harmony - this is fundamental to the prelude's design
commentary.pedagogy: The opening measure establishes the entire prelude's DNA. Notice how the arpeggiation spans from low C to high E, creating a harp-like wash of sound. The pattern will remain unchanged for 35 measures - only the harmonies shift beneath.
commentary.connections: This tonic establishes 'home' before the harmonic journey begins. The stability here makes later departures more meaningful.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Establishing even 16th notes and proper hand position
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Practice the pattern hands together slowly, feeling the 'lean' into beat 1 and 3. Keep wrist flexible.

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: ii6/5 (Dm7 in first inversion, F in bass)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-F-A-D-F pattern; LH: F bass, A as inner voice
notableFeatures: First chord change - the journey begins
Seventh chord adds dissonance requiring resolution
Bass moves up by step (C to D avoided by using F)
commentary.pedagogy: The ii6/5 is Bach's favorite pre-dominant. Notice the seventh (C) in the chord creating gentle tension. This is not just 'another chord' - it's the first step in a I-ii-V-I progression, one of the most fundamental in all tonal music.
commentary.connections: Creates forward motion from M1's stability. The F in bass provides smooth voice leading to the coming G.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Maintaining even rhythm during chord change
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Prepare the hand shape for measure 2 while still playing measure 1's last beats

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V6/5 (G7 in first inversion, B in bass)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-G pattern; LH: B bass, D/G inner voices
notableFeatures: Dominant seventh chord - maximum tension point in phrase
B in bass creates smooth descending line: C-F-B (tritone!)
Contains the leading tone (B) demanding resolution to C
The F in the chord is the dissonant 7th, pulling toward E
commentary.pedagogy: This V6/5 is textbook dominant function. The tritone between B and F creates the 'need' to resolve. Play measures 3-4 together and feel how M3 is 'incomplete' without M4's resolution. This tension-release pattern is the engine of tonal music.
commentary.connections: Directly resolves to M4's tonic. The bass descends B-C, the 7th (F) falls to E - both are obligatory voice-leading resolutions.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Pause on M3 and listen to the chord - can you feel it 'wanting' to resolve?

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-G-C-E-G pattern; LH: C bass, G inner voice
notableFeatures: Return to stability after dominant tension
Pattern identical to M1 but now feels like arrival, not departure
commentary.pedagogy: M1-4 form a complete harmonic phrase: I-ii6/5-V6/5-I. This is the same progression underlying countless pieces from Bach to the Beatles. Having experienced departure and return, we now have a template for understanding the entire prelude.
commentary.connections: This resolution is 'final' for the opening phrase, but M5 immediately begins a new journey to more distant harmonic regions.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Feeling the arrival without slowing down
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Lean slightly into beat 1 of M4 to emphasize resolution without disrupting tempo

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-A-C-E-A pattern; LH: A bass, E inner voice
notableFeatures: First move away from the I-V axis
A minor seventh chord - adding harmonic color
The relative minor creates a 'darkening' effect
commentary.pedagogy: The vi chord is the relative minor - it shares two notes with the tonic (C and E) but introduces a minor color. This is Bach showing us the harmonic landscape is richer than just I and V. The seventh makes it even more colorful.
commentary.connections: Begins a new harmonic journey. The A in bass is a third below C - circle of thirds motion complements circle of fifths.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Recognizing the shift in harmonic color
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Listen for the 'darkening' as you move from M4 to M5

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-A-C-D-F pattern; LH: D bass, A inner voice
notableFeatures: Pre-dominant function, now in root position
Continues the descending bass line: C-A-D (ascending 4th to D)
Second appearance of ii but in different inversion than M2
commentary.pedagogy: Compare this ii7 to M2's ii6/5. Same chord, different inversion, different context. In M2, it was part of the opening phrase. Here, it's part of a longer harmonic sequence. Context changes meaning even for identical harmonies.
commentary.connections: Connects vi (M5) to V (M7) - the classic ii-V-I turnaround underlying jazz and much classical music.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Maintaining forward motion through sequential passage
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Think of M5-8 as one long phrase, not four separate measures

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-F pattern; LH: G bass, B/D inner voices
notableFeatures: Root position dominant - more emphatic than M3's inversion
G in bass provides strong harmonic foundation
Creates strong pull toward tonic resolution in M8
The 7th (F) again demands resolution to E
commentary.pedagogy: This root-position V7 is more grounded than M3's V6/5. When the bass has the root, the chord has maximum stability within its function. The progression vi-ii-V (M5-6-7) is setting up a strong return to tonic.
commentary.connections: Resolves to M8. The bass motion G-C will create a perfect authentic cadence (V-I with both roots in bass).

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Allow a slight crescendo through M7 to M8

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: C-E-G-C-E pattern; LH: C bass, G inner voice
notableFeatures: Third statement of tonic - now as strong cadential arrival
Each tonic return is more 'earned' than the last
End of the exposition of basic harmonic material
commentary.pedagogy: We've now heard two complete progressions: M1-4 and M5-8. The first was I-ii-V-I, the second was vi-ii-V-I. Both end on tonic but started differently. Bach is showing us that there are multiple paths home.
commentary.connections: M9 will begin the development section, venturing further afield. This is the last 'comfortable' tonic for a while.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Feel the arrival but maintain strict tempo - the music continues!

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-A-C-E-A pattern; LH: A bass, E inner voice
notableFeatures: Same notes as M5 but new function - pointing toward G major
Beginning of modulation to the dominant key
Secondary function: ii of V (leading to V of C)
The music begins looking toward G major as a goal
commentary.pedagogy: Recontextualization! This Am7 has identical notes to M5 but now functions differently. In M5, it was vi of C. Here, it's ii of G - a pre-dominant of the dominant. Same chord, different meaning. This is sophisticated harmonic thinking.
commentary.connections: Sets up V/V in M10 (if we read it that way) or simply moves through the circle of fifths toward G.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Hearing the shift in harmonic function
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Think of M9-10 as moving toward G rather than away from C

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V (G major, functioning as I of the dominant region)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-G pattern; LH: G bass, B/D inner voices
notableFeatures: Arrival on dominant - but no 7th yet
G major as a temporary tonic
Moment of stability within the dominant region
Prepares for the secondary dominant sequence to come
commentary.pedagogy: Bach briefly treats G major as if it were the tonic. This technique - 'tonicizing' the dominant - creates a sense of expansion. We're not in C anymore, nor fully in G, but somewhere in between. Harmonic ambiguity creates interest.
commentary.connections: From here, Bach will begin a chain of secondary dominants, each one leading to the next chord in a circle of fifths.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Think of M10 as a moment of arrival before the sequence begins

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V7/vi (E7 - secondary dominant of A minor)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-G#-B-E-G# pattern; LH: E bass, B inner voice
notableFeatures: First chromatic note (G#) - outside C major scale
Secondary dominant pointing to A minor
The raised G creates urgency and forward drive
commentary.pedagogy: The G# is a shock to the ear trained on C major. This E7 is 'borrowed' from A minor and demands resolution to Am. Secondary dominants are 'temporary visitors' that point to the next chord. Each one creates its own small tension-resolution.
commentary.connections: Resolves to vi (Am) in M12. This begins a chain: V/vi - vi - V/ii - ii - V/V - V, etc.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Hear the G# as a 'brightening' of the chord, pulling toward A

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-A-C-E-A pattern; LH: A bass, E inner voice
notableFeatures: Now serves as a link in the chain sequence
Same notes as M5 and M9 - three different contexts!
Beginning of the 'chain of fifths' sequential passage
commentary.pedagogy: We've heard this Am sonority three times now (M5, M9, M12), each time with different meaning. This is the genius of tonal harmony - context determines function. Here, Am is a stepping stone in a descending fifths sequence.
commentary.connections: M12 leads to M13 (V/ii), then to M14 (ii), continuing the chain down by fifths.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Feel the sequence as one long line, not individual measures

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V7/ii (A7 - secondary dominant of D minor)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-A-C#-E-G pattern; LH: A bass, G inner voice
notableFeatures: Second chromatic note (C#) - pointing to D minor
A becomes its own dominant by adding the C#
Major quality of A7 contrasts with previous Am
commentary.pedagogy: The Am of M12 transforms into A7 (dominant of D). This is called 'mutating' a chord - it keeps the root but changes quality to point to the next destination. The C# creates the leading tone to D.
commentary.connections: Resolves to ii (Dm) in M14. The sequence continues its inexorable descent.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Notice how M12's A minor becomes M13's A major - same root, different color

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-A-D-F-A pattern; LH: D bass, A inner voice
commentary.pedagogy: The sequence has brought us to D minor, the ii chord. Notice how naturally we arrived here through the chain of fifths. Each link (V/x - x) creates its own mini-resolution while propelling the larger progression forward.
commentary.connections: M15 will tonicize G (the dominant), continuing toward the structural dominant.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Think ahead to where the sequence is going

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-F#-C-D-F# pattern; LH: D bass, A/C inner voices
notableFeatures: Third chromatic note (F#) - pointing to G
D minor mutates to D major (D7)
This dominant of the dominant is harmonically significant
Creates strong pull toward the structural dominant
commentary.pedagogy: The V/V is one of the most important secondary dominants. It's a 'double dominant' - dominant of the dominant. The F# is the leading tone of G, creating powerful forward motion. We're building toward a major structural point.
commentary.connections: Resolves to V (G) in M16. This is the culmination of the sequential passage.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: The F# should 'shine' slightly - it's the leading tone of G

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-G pattern; LH: G bass, B inner voice
notableFeatures: Arrival on structural dominant after sequential buildup
Resolution of the entire M11-15 sequence
Moment of relative stability within the dominant
commentary.pedagogy: The sequential chain (E7-Am-A7-Dm-D7-G) has reached its goal: the dominant. This is a major structural arrival. The sequence was not random wandering but a directed journey to this point. Hierarchy in harmony!
commentary.connections: M17 begins a new section with another secondary dominant sequence, now exploring the subdominant region.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: This is the first major 'pillar' after the opening - give it appropriate weight

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-Bb-C-E-G pattern; LH: C bass, Bb inner voice
notableFeatures: First Bb in the piece - pointing to F major
C becomes dominant of F by adding the Bb
Continuing the secondary dominant chain in new direction
commentary.pedagogy: After establishing the dominant, Bach now looks toward the subdominant. The Bb is the flat-7 of C, turning it into a dominant seventh pointing to F. This expands the harmonic palette in the opposite direction from M11-16.
commentary.connections: Resolves to IV (F) in M18. The exploration of subdominant creates balance with earlier dominant exploration.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: The Bb should sound like a gentle 'lowering' compared to the natural B

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: C-F-A-C-F pattern; LH: F bass, A inner voice
notableFeatures: First clear F major since the opening
Warm, stable sonority after chromatic tension
Subdominant provides contrast to dominant emphasis
commentary.pedagogy: The IV chord is the 'other direction' from the tonic - subdominant rather than dominant. It provides a warm, 'plagal' color. Bach balances dominant and subdominant exploration to create a complete harmonic picture.
commentary.connections: M19 introduces the most dramatic chromatic chord yet, intensifying toward the climax.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Let the F major sound 'open' and warm - it's a moment of relative calm

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: viio7/V (F#dim7 - diminished seventh leading to G)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: C-Eb-F#-A-C pattern; LH: F# bass, A/C inner voices
notableFeatures: Most dissonant chord so far - fully diminished seventh
F# in bass creates strongest pull toward G
Two chromatic notes (F# and Eb) simultaneously
commentary.pedagogy: The diminished seventh is the most unstable chord in tonal harmony - every note wants to resolve. The F# pulls up to G, the Eb pulls down to D. This chord creates almost unbearable tension before the climax.
commentary.connections: Resolves dramatically to M20's V6/5. This is the peak of harmonic tension in the piece.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Allow this measure to 'pull' toward M20 - don't resolve early!

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-F pattern; LH: B bass, D/F inner voices
notableFeatures: Same chord as M3 but now as structural highpoint
B in bass creates urgency for tonic resolution
commentary.pedagogy: After the extreme tension of M19, this V6/5 is both resolution and new tension. It resolves the diminished seventh but creates dominant tension of its own. This is the climactic turning point - the 'top of the arch' before descent to final resolution.
commentary.connections: Begins the long descent toward the final tonic. Everything from here leads home.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: This is the emotional highpoint - let it speak without forcing

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: I6 (C major first inversion - E in bass)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-G-C-E-G pattern; LH: E bass, G/C inner voices
notableFeatures: First inversion tonic - resolution but not complete
E in bass creates ongoing motion
Alternation of I and V inversions begins
commentary.pedagogy: The first inversion tonic is resolution but with a 'but...' attached. The E in bass keeps the music moving. Bach begins a series of alternating I6 and V chords that gradually settle toward final resolution.
commentary.connections: Alternates with M22's V4/3, creating a 'stepping down' pattern toward the pedal point.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: This resolves M20 but doesn't feel 'final' - the bass E keeps things moving

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V4/3 (G7 second inversion - F in bass)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-F pattern; LH: F bass, B/D inner voices
notableFeatures: F in bass creates strong downward pull
Part of the alternating I-V pattern
commentary.pedagogy: The V4/3 has the 7th (F) in the bass - the most unstable note of the chord in the lowest position. This creates maximum urgency for resolution. The bass alternation E-F-E mimics the final cadential pattern to come.
commentary.connections: Resolves to I6 in M23, continuing the alternating pattern.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: The bass F should 'lean' downward toward the coming E

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-G-C-E-G pattern; LH: E bass, G/C inner voices
commentary.pedagogy: The repetition of I6-V4/3-I6 creates a 'rocking' motion that builds anticipation. We know we're headed somewhere, but each resolution is incomplete. This delayed gratification makes the final arrival more satisfying.
commentary.connections: M24 will move to V6, beginning the approach to the dominant pedal.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Even though this repeats M21, feel the ongoing progression

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V6 (G major first inversion - B in bass)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-G pattern; LH: B bass, D inner voice
notableFeatures: B in bass (leading tone) creates strong pull
commentary.pedagogy: This V6 (without the 7th) is 'lighter' than the V7 chords we've heard. It creates dominant function but with less urgency. Bach is preparing for the final section rather than creating immediate resolution pressure.
commentary.connections: Moves to I in M25, which begins the final preparation for the closing pedal point.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Compare this to M22 - no F means less tension

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: C-E-G-C-E pattern; LH: C bass, G inner voice
notableFeatures: Root position tonic - most stable position
First truly stable tonic since M8
C in bass anchors the return
commentary.pedagogy: After all the inversions and alternations, root position C major feels like coming home. This is the first really stable tonic in a long time. But we're not done yet - Bach has one more journey to make before the end.
commentary.connections: M26 begins exploring subdominant region one final time before the pedal point.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: This is NOT the final cadence - maintain forward motion

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V6/5/IV (C7 first inversion - secondary dominant of F)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: C-E-Bb-C-E pattern; LH: E bass, Bb inner voice
notableFeatures: Return of Bb - pointing to F again
E in bass with Bb creates tritone
commentary.pedagogy: One last detour! The V7/IV returns, reminding us of M17's subdominant exploration. Bach creates a final moment of harmonic richness before the long dominant pedal. The Bb is a 'farewell' to chromaticism.
commentary.connections: Resolves to IV in M27, then quickly returns to dominant territory.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Clean Bb after return to diatonic context
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: This Bb is the last significant chromatic note - let it 'color' the passage

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: C-F-A-C-F pattern; LH: F bass, A inner voice
notableFeatures: Last visit to F major region
commentary.pedagogy: This F major has a 'farewell' quality. We've visited the subdominant region for the last time. From here, everything moves toward dominant and final resolution. The warmth of IV contrasts with the dominant tension to come.
commentary.connections: M28 introduces the leading tone chord, beginning the final cadential approach.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Allow a slight warmth here - it's the last subdominant moment

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: viio6/5 (Bdim7 first inversion - D in bass)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-F-Ab-B-D pattern; LH: D bass, Ab inner voice
commentary.pedagogy: The viio7 is V7 without the root - pure leading-tone function. Every note of this diminished seventh pulls toward resolution. The Ab is particularly poignant, desperately wanting to resolve down to G.
commentary.connections: Resolves to I6 in M29, continuing the approach to the dominant pedal.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: This is high tension - don't over-accent but do allow the dissonance

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-G-C-E-G pattern; LH: E bass, G inner voice
notableFeatures: E in bass part of descending line
commentary.pedagogy: Another first inversion tonic - stable but not final. The bass is working its way down: F-E-D... preparing for the low G that will anchor the dominant pedal. Resolution within ongoing motion.
commentary.connections: M30 will provide another V4/3, continuing toward the pedal point.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: We're almost home but not there yet - keep the forward lean

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-F pattern; LH: F bass, B/D inner voices
notableFeatures: F in bass creating strong resolution pressure
commentary.pedagogy: The V4/3 returns, its bass F pushing down toward E. But this time, instead of going to I6, we're headed for the dominant pedal. The bass is about to lock onto G and stay there.
commentary.connections: M31 provides one more I6 before the bass finally reaches and holds G.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: The bass F is about to give way to the long G pedal

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: E-G-C-E-G pattern; LH: E bass, G/C inner voices
notableFeatures: Final first inversion tonic before pedal
Bass E will step down to D then G
Last moment of harmonic motion before stasis
commentary.pedagogy: This is the last 'mobile' harmony before the bass locks onto the dominant pedal. The progression F-E (M30-31) continues to D (implied) and then G. We're entering the final phase of the piece.
commentary.connections: M32 begins the dominant pedal - the bass will hold G for four measures.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Listen for how the bass 'settles' into the coming G

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-G pattern; LH: G pedal bass, inner voice motion above
notableFeatures: Bass G will hold for four measures
Upper voices continue pattern over held bass
commentary.pedagogy: The dominant pedal is the ultimate tension-builder. By holding the G in the bass for four measures while harmonies shift above, Bach creates a sense of 'waiting' for resolution. The longer we wait, the more satisfying the arrival.
commentary.connections: M33-34 continue the pedal with increasing dissonance above.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Sustaining the bass G while playing other notes
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Think of the bass G as an 'anchor' that holds everything in place

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: D-G-B-D-F pattern; LH: G pedal, with 7th (F) appearing above
notableFeatures: F in upper voice pulls toward E
commentary.pedagogy: The 7th is added to the dominant pedal, creating more tension. The F wants to resolve to E (which it will in the final chord). The pedal continues its inexorable hold while tension builds above it.
commentary.connections: M34 will continue the pedal with even more elaborate dissonance.

measureByMeasure.difficultyNotes: Voicing the seventh clearly over pedal
measureByMeasure.practiceTips: The F should 'lean' toward its eventual resolution to E

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: V7 (G7 with suspensions and passing tones)
commentary.voiceActivity: RH: Complex figuration with C-Eb-D resolution; LH: G pedal continues
notableFeatures: Most elaborate measure of the pedal section
commentary.pedagogy: This is the climax of the pedal section. The Eb passing tone creates a momentary diminished quality, adding one last touch of chromaticism before the final pure C major. Maximum tension before maximum release.
commentary.connections: Resolves to the final tonic in M35 - the goal of the entire piece.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: This is the 'last breath' before the final chord - make it count

commentary.voiceActivity: RH: C-E-G-C-E (full arpeggiation resolving); LH: C bass, final resolution
notableFeatures: Return to opening sonority with new meaning
The C major 'earned' through harmonic adventure
commentary.pedagogy: The final C major is the same notes as M1 but carries the weight of everything we've experienced. Every departure, every chromatic adventure, every tension and resolution has led to this moment. This is what 'home' means in music.
commentary.connections: This tonic is both an ending and preparation for the Fugue to come.

measureByMeasure.practiceTips: Let the final chord ring - this is the moment we've been waiting for

subjectAnalysis.description: Stepwise subject outlining the tonic triad with characteristic rhythm
subjectAnalysis.intervals: Ascending stepwise motion with leap to dominant, descending return
subjectAnalysis.rhythm: Half note beginning, quarter notes, characteristic 8th-note figure
subjectAnalysis.character: Stately, diatonic, clearly defining C major
subjectAnalysis.technicalNotes: Subject spans an octave, requires smooth legato

answerAnalysis.relationship: Subject in tonic, Answer in dominant - standard fugal procedure

countersubjectAnalysis.description: Conjunct motion in 8th notes, provides rhythmic contrast to subject
countersubjectAnalysis.character: Flowing, continuous 8th notes against the subject's longer values

sections.name: Exposition
sections.description: All four voices enter with Subject/Answer

subjectEntries: Soprano enters with Subject in C major

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Subject; A/T/B: Silent
notableFeatures: Subject begins on C (tonic), rises to G (dominant)
commentary.pedagogy: The Subject is the fugue's DNA - everything else derives from it. Bach presents it alone so we can memorize its contour. The rising motion from C to G outlines the tonic-dominant axis that will govern the entire fugue.
commentary.connections: This subject will appear in all four voices and in multiple keys. Learn its shape - you'll hear it everywhere.

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Subject conclusion; A/T/B: Silent
commentary.pedagogy: The Subject's two-measure span is typical for Bach. Note the rhythmic variety: half notes, quarters, and eighths. The subject ends on G, leaving harmonic 'room' for the Answer to begin.
commentary.connections: The Alto will enter with the Answer in M3, transposed to the dominant.

subjectEntries: Alto enters with Answer (transposed to G)

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Countersubject (8th notes); A: Answer
notableFeatures: Soprano moves in 8ths while Alto has longer values
commentary.pedagogy: The Answer in the dominant is fundamental to fugal structure - it 'answers' the tonic Subject with a dominant response. Meanwhile, the Countersubject (Soprano) provides continuous motion. This S-CS pairing will recur throughout.
commentary.connections: The Countersubject will accompany nearly every subject entry. Listen for its 8th-note motion.

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Countersubject conclusion; A: Answer conclusion
notableFeatures: Answer concludes on D (dominant of dominant)
Texture ready for third voice entry
commentary.pedagogy: The S-A combination establishes the primary contrapuntal relationship. Note how they complement each other: when one voice moves, the other often holds or moves in contrary motion. This is the art of counterpoint.
commentary.connections: M5 brings the Tenor with the Subject, now in three-voice texture.

subjectEntries: Tenor enters with Subject in C major

commentary.harmonicAnalysis: I (return to tonic for third entry)
commentary.voiceActivity: S: Free counterpoint; A: Countersubject; T: Subject
commentary.pedagogy: The third entry returns to tonic (C major), following the standard S-D-T pattern. Notice how the Countersubject 'transfers' from Soprano to Alto. This fluidity of material between voices is essential to fugal texture.
commentary.connections: One more voice to go - Bass will enter in M7 with the Answer.

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Free counterpoint; A: Countersubject; T: Subject conclusion
commentary.pedagogy: With three voices active, the contrapuntal density increases. Each voice has independent motion while contributing to the harmonic whole. This is the texture of learned counterpoint that Bach perfected.
commentary.connections: M7 completes the exposition with Bass entry.

subjectEntries: Bass enters with Answer in G

commentary.voiceActivity: S/A: Free counterpoint; T: Countersubject; B: Answer
commentary.pedagogy: The exposition is complete! All four voices have stated the Subject or Answer: S (Subject), A (Answer), T (Subject), B (Answer). This alternation of S-A-S-A ensures harmonic balance between tonic and dominant.
commentary.connections: After M8, episodes and middle entries will develop the material.

commentary.voiceActivity: All four voices active
commentary.pedagogy: The exposition has presented all the material we need. From here, Bach will explore this material: different keys, different combinations, episodes that develop motives from the Subject and Countersubject.
commentary.connections: M9 begins the development with middle entries.

subjectEntries: Subject entry in Alto (A minor region)

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Countersubject; A: Subject in vi; T/B: Accompaniment
notableFeatures: First subject entry in new key
commentary.pedagogy: Middle entries explore the Subject in related keys. A minor (vi) is the relative minor of C major - closely related but with different color. This expands the fugue's harmonic range while maintaining thematic unity.
commentary.connections: More middle entries will follow, exploring other key areas.

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Countersubject conclusion; A: Subject conclusion; T/B: Support
notableFeatures: Preparing for next entry or episode
commentary.pedagogy: The Subject in minor mode sounds darker, more intense. The same notes in a different context create different emotional meaning. This is the power of modal variety in fugal development.
commentary.connections: The music will modulate or sequence toward the next entry point.

subjectEntries: Subject entry in Bass (G major region)

commentary.voiceActivity: Upper voices: Counterpoint; B: Subject in V
commentary.pedagogy: The dominant key is the most important related key. A Subject entry here reinforces the tonic-dominant polarity that governs the fugue. The Bass provides both thematic and harmonic foundation.
commentary.connections: More development continues, building toward the next structural point.

commentary.voiceActivity: Full four-voice texture
commentary.pedagogy: Extended time in the dominant creates expectation for return to tonic. The dominant's instability makes us 'want' resolution. Bach controls this tension carefully.
commentary.connections: An episode may follow to provide contrast and modulate.

commentary.voiceActivity: All voices with fragmentary motives
commentary.pedagogy: Episodes use fragments of the Subject and Countersubject in sequences. They provide contrast to the entries and allow harmonic motion to new key areas. This is 'development' in the truest sense.
commentary.connections: The sequence will lead to the next subject entry.

commentary.voiceActivity: Interlocking sequences in all voices
commentary.pedagogy: Sequential episodes create forward momentum through repetition at different pitch levels. Each repetition builds expectation. The listener recognizes the pattern and anticipates where it leads.
commentary.connections: M15 will likely bring a new Subject entry.

subjectEntries: Subject entry in Soprano (return toward tonic)

commentary.voiceActivity: S: Subject; A: Countersubject; T/B: Support
notableFeatures: Soprano takes Subject - return to opening voice
commentary.pedagogy: The Soprano's return with the Subject is significant - it mirrors the opening. This cyclical element gives the fugue architectural coherence. We sense we're approaching a major structural point.
commentary.connections: The fugue begins building toward its final section.

commentary.voiceActivity: Full texture with Subject in Soprano
commentary.pedagogy: Each return to the tonic with the Subject feels like 'coming home.' But Bach isn't finished - more development and a final intensification remain before the conclusion.
commentary.connections: M17-20 may include stretto or other intensifying devices.

commentary.voiceActivity: T: Subject; other voices: counterpoint
commentary.pedagogy: In the later stages of a fugue, entries often come closer together. This 'compression' creates intensity. The texture becomes more complex as we approach the end.
commentary.connections: Stretto entries may begin soon.

commentary.voiceActivity: Rich four-voice texture
commentary.pedagogy: The texture is now at its most complex. All four voices are fully engaged, and the harmonic rhythm may increase. Bach is building toward the final climactic section.
commentary.connections: M19-20 lead to the final entries.

commentary.voiceActivity: Overlapping Subject entries
commentary.pedagogy: Stretto is the ultimate fugal technique - Subject entries that overlap before the previous entry finishes. This creates maximum intensity. It's Bach showing mastery: the Subject works in combination with itself!
commentary.connections: Stretto leads to the final cadential approach.

commentary.voiceActivity: Maximum complexity
commentary.pedagogy: This is the fugue's climax - the point of maximum contrapuntal and harmonic intensity. From here, Bach will guide us toward the final cadence. The complexity will gradually resolve.
commentary.connections: M21-23 begin the descent toward conclusion.

commentary.voiceActivity: Texture beginning to clarify
commentary.pedagogy: After the stretto climax, the texture begins to clarify. The harmony moves toward the final cadence. This is the 'unwinding' after the point of maximum tension.
commentary.connections: M24-27 will bring the final resolution.

commentary.voiceActivity: Moving toward homophony
commentary.pedagogy: The pre-cadential episode prepares the listener for the end. The texture may become somewhat more homophonic, and the harmony emphasizes the dominant in preparation for the final tonic.
commentary.connections: Final cadence approaching.

commentary.voiceActivity: Final Subject presentation
commentary.pedagogy: The final Subject statement brings the fugue full circle. We hear the theme one last time before the closing cadence. It's a moment of thematic homecoming that parallels the harmonic return to tonic.
commentary.connections: M24-27 complete the fugue.

commentary.voiceActivity: Full four-voice texture
commentary.pedagogy: The final measures confirm the tonic through clear cadential motion. After all the contrapuntal complexity, the harmony returns to simple, clear function: dominant to tonic, tension to resolution.
commentary.connections: Final cadence imminent.

commentary.voiceActivity: Cadential voicing
commentary.pedagogy: The final cadence uses conventional V-I motion, but with all the weight of the preceding fugue behind it. Every voice leads to its final destination. The contrapuntal journey ends in harmonic clarity.
commentary.connections: M26-27 conclude the fugue.

commentary.voiceActivity: Moving to final chord
commentary.pedagogy: The final measures may include cadential decoration - suspensions, passing tones, or rhythmic elongation. These emphasize the finality of the ending and give the conclusion proper weight.
commentary.connections: M27 brings the final chord.

commentary.voiceActivity: All voices on final chord
commentary.pedagogy: The final chord is the goal of the entire fugue. All four voices arrive at notes of the C major chord, all tensions resolved, all motion completed. This is the 'Q.E.D.' of the fugal argument.
commentary.connections: This concludes BWV 846. The first of 48 Preludes and Fugues stands complete.

preludeKeyTakeaways: Broken chord figuration as sole texture - harmony IS the content
Progressive harmonic journey: I - departures - chromaticism - return
Chain of secondary dominants creates forward motion
Dominant pedal creates maximum tension before final resolution
Same tonic sonority means different things at different structural points
fugueKeyTakeaways: Exposition presents Subject in all four voices (alternating tonic/dominant)
Middle entries explore related keys (vi, V, etc.)
Stretto creates climactic intensity through overlapping entries
Final section brings thematic and harmonic resolution
practiceRecommendations: Prelude: First learn the hand shape for each chord, then connect them
Prelude: Listen for harmonic color changes, not just notes
Fugue: Learn to hear and identify the Subject in all four voices
Fugue: Practice each voice separately, then in pairs, then all together
Both: Understand the structure before focusing on speed
